Uploaded patch set 15: Patch Set 14 was rebased.
Uploaded patch set 16: Commit message was updated.
Change has been successfully merged by Rui
Can you add a message to this .debug() call? Something like "listVms() failed".
how about req.log.error()?  Seems more appropriate, no?

Some more detail would be good:

> It's better to preprovision NICs up front so that issues like running out of IP addresses or being unable to provide an explicitly requested IP address can be reported back to the customer, instead of silently disappearing in the workflow job's details.
next() is called a second time here. It looks like the second call is the one that should be removed.
An incomplete attempt at consistent return. Fixed.

This needs to call "next(err)" before returning.

Alternatively, if we fail to release the ticket, is it okay to just drive on and it gets released later? I've never dealt with the waitlist tickets, so someone else should probably chime in here.

Good catch.

I would also appreciate some guidance here. I think the tickets eventually expire.  If we short-circuit here we should clean up properly, but if we don't the VM should still be able to complete provisioning.

Current code also has a missing callback, but does "ignore" the error.
https://github.com/joyent/sdc-vmapi/blob/master/lib/workflows/job-common.js#L1481

I am inclined, without further guidance, to log the warning and drive on.
We can use req.cnapi here instead of making a new client, right? It looks like VMAPI's wrapper has a .getServer().
Since CloudAPI will normally provision using "uuid", it might be best to leave this test the way it was.
I think I was testing this on RAN early on and it was getting stuck here.  I changed it back.

Why did you change this test? It looks like it's meant to pass through here:

https://github.com/joyent/sdc-designation/blob/master/lib/algorithms/hard-filter-force-failure.js#L36

This tests to see if we properly clean up NICs after a DAPI provision failure.  

With my changes we do DAPI allocation first, and then provision NICs.  So triggering a DAPI failure would occur before we try to provision NICs, and not properly test preprovision NIC cleanup.

This array is to handle the case where a VM has been provisioned on the same fabric network multiple times. If it has, then we'll skip pushing the second and onwards NICs on the network into the "nics" array.
I see.  I saw this in passing, and left a note to check back.  Looks like I forgot to do that.

The method of adding NICs by passing the MAC addresses is primarily used by CloudAPI (although it's also used by manta-adm for example). CloudAPI does it because it wants to return the NIC information to the user, and it isn't currently able to do that by specifying network UUIDs without digging around in the job status. Because CloudAPI returns once VMAPI returns the job UUID, if the job fails there's nothing to clean up the NICs that were created.
That seems like a valid case but I think we are still going to have the side effect I mention.  Although maybe that is not as common (or possible via supported APIs)?
Yes, it's not currently possible through our user-facing APIs to create a NIC, and then later assign it to a VM.
Since this line is changing, might as well name the function.
This was intended for my own debugging, clearly, but I think it might be a good addition for the DEBUG level logging...
I think this name is confusing in light of what addNics() does. This function loads nic objects into req.add_nics, while addNics() kicks off a job.

Why are we getting something we just created?

As far as I can tell, we're solely doing a GET call so we can check the status in waitOnAllocationTicket(), but calling cnapi.waitlistTicketWait() directly achieves what we want anyway? It's the same number of calls in the best case, and one extra call in the worst for the existing code.

Seems unnecessary, unless I missed something.
Used heavily within allocateServer(); assign to its own var at allocateServer()'s outermost scope.
Might be worth assigning to its own var.
Same question as with the allocationTicket GET.

Worth assigning to own var, particularly if that req.vmTicket below is a typo.

Also, under which circumstances is this expression true?

that's what happens when one copies code ;) 

Fixed.
Under what circumstances is this true?

This has changed, but in the new code:

When any func before "allocateServer()" in the createVm pipeline fails, or anything prior to "acquireVMTicket()" in "allocateServer()" fails

Part of TRITON-9 requires that the VM be updated with server_uuid before any other dapi executions (aka before the release of allocationTicket).

It looks like only the local copy of vm is updated with server_uuid before release, not the object in moray?
Complicated enough to deserve a name.
but then it would require iterating over the entire array, whereas in this case it short circuits upon satisfaction.

Since this is used three times in this func, probably worth assigning to its own var.

Every time we get an attribute value, that's a chance for a typo and an undefined to creep in.

Could just be:

var networks = req.filteredNetworks.networks;
Could assign to its own var, since used three times.
Oh my. How do we end up with empty strings here?
You may want to set jobLocation to null inside this test, in case anyone ever adds a new test before here that also sets and uses the variable.
